articles.description: MPO’s creation reflects PM’s belief that government and its agencies need to better and more swiftly row in the same direction

articles.title: Scientists find brain cells that could stop Alzheimer’s
articles.description: Researchers have identified special immune cells in the brain that help slow Alzheimer’s. These microglia work to reduce inflammation and block the spread of harmful proteins. They appear to protect memory and brain health, offering a promising new direction for therapy.

articles.title: Why Are We All Still Carrying Around Car Keys?
articles.description: Ford wants you to stash it in your belt buckle, but there’s absolutely no need to be lugging around a bulky fob. Trouble is, phone-as-a-key tech could be superseded before it even gets going.

articles.title: New laser treatment could stop blindness before it starts
articles.description: Aalto University scientists have created a laser-based treatment that uses gentle heat to stop the progression of dry macular degeneration. The approach stimulates the eye’s natural cleanup and repair systems to protect against blindness.

articles.title: Kenyan activists missing in Uganda found safe after five weeks
articles.description: The pair were reportedly bundled into a car by masked men after attending an event to support Ugandan opposition leader Bobi Wine.

articles.title: MIT quantum breakthrough edges toward room-temp superconductors
articles.description: MIT scientists uncovered direct evidence of unconventional superconductivity in magic-angle graphene by observing a distinctive V-shaped energy gap. The discovery hints that electron pairing in this material may arise from strong electronic interactions instead of lattice vibrations.

articles.title: Einstein might have been wrong about black holes
articles.description: Researchers are using black hole shadows to challenge Einstein’s theory of relativity. With new simulations and future ultra-sharp telescope images, they may uncover signs that his famous equations don’t tell the whole story.

articles.title: Deep-sea mining starves life in the ocean’s twilight zone
articles.description: Scientists have discovered that deep-sea mining plumes can strip vital nutrition from the ocean’s twilight zone, replacing natural food with nutrient-poor sediment. The resulting “junk food” effect could starve life across entire marine ecosystems.

articles.title: Letters to The Vancouver Sun: City council and park board can work together
articles.description: Nov. 8 letters to The Vancouver Sun.

articles.title: Laser satellites expose a secret Antarctic carbon burst
articles.description: A new study shows that the Southern Ocean releases far more carbon dioxide in winter than once thought. By combining laser satellite data with AI analysis, scientists managed to “see” through the polar darkness for the first time. The results reveal a 40% undercount in winter emissions, changing how
